info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 28.

(1, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Giza, Egypt.)  After seeing the Sphinx he wrote in "Innocents Abroad", "The great face was so sad, so earnest, so longing"

(2, 1).clue: In 1975, using her grandkids' ages, a Pennsylvania woman won about $28,000 with this alliterative racetrack bet

(3, 1).clue: Grant quipped, "I only know 2 tunes.  One is" this patriotic tune "and the other one isn't"

(5, 1).clue: Among his top 10 "worst names for a seafood restaurant" were "The Gagging Deck Hand" & "It Might Be Flounder"

(6, 1).clue: A type of mustache, or a bicycle's steering rod

(1, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Luxor, Egypt.)  Lady Herbert, daughter of this lord, was at the opening of Tut's tomb & lived to age 79--so much for the curse!

(2, 2).clue: Anything that gives you a solution to a mystery, or a Parker Brothers board game

(3, 2).clue: The U.S. city where he's entombed

(5, 2).clue: Chris Rock doesn't think gun control is necessary, as "long as" these "cost $5,000"

(6, 2).clue: To be or not to be this type of small village, that is the question (or in this case, the answer)

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Luxor, Egypt.)  When he invaded Egypt in 1798 he said, "Soldiers, from atop of these pyramids, 40 centuries are looking at us"

(2, 3).clue: 5-letter term used to show feelings of regret, or a Parker Brothers board game; ooo...

(5, 3).clue: One real headline featured on his talk show read, "Holidays make child's dream of shiny, new ax a reality"

(6, 3).clue: The emblem the Soviet Union adopted in 1923

(1, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Giza, Egypt.)  In a letter, this 19th century limerick poet wrote about riding a camel, "Away you go, just as if on a rocking chair"

(2, 4).clue: From the French for "rotten pot", it's any mixture of unrelated objects

(3, 4).clue: The newspaper publisher he defeated in 1872 to win his second term

(5, 4).clue: You wouldn't be wrong if you knew this comic said, "Curiosity killed the cat, but for a while I was a suspect"

(6, 4).clue: C'mon, take a chance, just for this flatfish, genus Hippoglossus

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Luxor, Egypt.)  One of the people behind moving the other obelisk to Paris was this decipherer of the Rosetta Stone

(2, 5).clue: Don't look now, but from the Latin for "balcony", it's a small platform for a public speaker

(3, 5).clue: Grant & Lee's battle of attrition in the forest May 5-7, 1864

(5, 5).clue: This "Brain Droppings" author said, "If you love someone, set them free; if they come home, set them on fire"

(6, 5).clue: The music for this Cuban dance has a slow duple meter

(1, 1).clue: Basquiat got attention, not detention, for this type of wall writing in "Hollywood Africans"

(3, 1).clue: Abe Lincoln lived in this city in the 1840s & '50s; his home still stands at Eighth & Jackson

(4, 1).clue: A scratch player in golf is one who plays without this

(5, 1).clue: In the '30s Miller attended this school at Ann Arbor, which he said was "regarded as a radical enclave"

(6, 1).clue: Able to live both on land & in water

(1, 2).clue: Her large installations "The Dinner Party" & "The Holocaust Project" have been published in book form

(2, 2).clue: Say hello to my Cuban drug lord Tony Montana

(3, 2).clue: "Will it play in" this city, headquarters of the earthmoving Caterpillar, Inc.

(4, 2).clue: Used for flogging, it takes its name from the feline scratch-like marks it left on its victims

(5, 2).clue: Speaking of this play, Miller said, "The threat of this kind of hysteria is never really gone.  It's with us always"

(6, 2).clue: Geographically, it precedes "City" in Iowa & "Falls" in South Dakota

(1, 3).clue: Neo-expressionest Julian Schnabel changed canvases & directed this film about Cuban poet Reinaldo Arenas

(3, 3).clue: Illinois' southernmost city, it shares its name with Africa's largest city (pronounced differently)

(4, 3).clue: In nine-ball, whenever you sink this, it's a scratch

(5, 3).clue: Brian Dennehy, seen here playing "Jeopardy!" in 1999, played this Miller character on Broadway that same year

(6, 3).clue: Thrill to this word meaning "performed in place of another", from the Latin for "substitute"

(1, 4).clue: Christo had the idea for the Central Park project with this title in 1979; it was finally realized in 2005

(3, 4).clue: 2 state penitentiaries are in or near this northeastern Illinois city, the seat of Will County

(4, 4).clue: This nocturnal mammal's name comes from an Algonquin word for "he scratches with his hands"

(5, 4).clue: This scathingly personal drama portrayed Marilyn Monroe as a singer named Maggie

(6, 4).clue: From the Latin for "propitiate", it means earnestly religious

(1, 5).clue: This artist who died in 1990 created "Radiant Baby", which is sold at his art store in New York City

(3, 5).clue: Here's "de" story; barbed wire was first perfected & manufactured in this city

(4, 5).clue: In the Old South he was sometimes known as "Old Scratch"

(5, 5).clue: Miller is seen here receiving this highest honor the United States gives for a life of creativity

(6, 5).clue: Don't "object" to this 13-letter adjective that means scrupulous or meticulous

(0, 0).clue: In this language spoken by 120 million worldwide, all of the days of the week but one end with the same 3 letters
